qas.question: Species that rely on few or a single prey are called?
Predator and prey relationships that improve fitness for both species are classified as this type of relationship.
Give an example of an animal that will travel several miles in a single day.
What plant associated with kissing during the holidays is also parasitic?
How are parasites distiguished from grazers?

answers.text: close association with their host species

qas.question: How many hosts do parasites typically have?

answers.text: one or at most a few in their lifetime

qas.question: How should parasite classification be viewed instead of as four isolated forms?
What does the term symbiosis mean?
What kind of relationship do grazers have with their host more so than parasites?

plausible_answers.text: one or at most a few

qas.question: Cholera is limited to how many spots to feed in its lifetime?
What is another word for macroscopic?
How many forms are used to classify a single plant?
What is damaged in a mutual relationship?

context: <a0_0>Parasites<a0_0/> can at times be difficult to distinguish from grazers. Their feeding behavior is similar in many ways, however they are noted for their <a4_0><b8_0>close<b8_0/> association with their host species<a4_0/>. While a grazing species such as an <a2_0>elephant<a2_0/> may travel many kilometers in a single day, grazing on many plants in the process, parasites form very close associations with their hosts, usually having only <a5_0><b9_0>one or at most a few<b9_0/> in their lifetime<a5_0/>. This close living arrangement may be described by the term symbiosis, <b10_0>"<a7_0>living together<a7_0/>"<b10_0/>, but unlike <a1_0>mutualism<a1_0/> the association significantly reduces <b12_0>the fitness of the host<b12_0/>. Parasitic organisms range from the macroscopic <a3_0>mistletoe<a3_0/>, a parasitic plant, to microscopic internal parasites such as cholera. Some species however have more loose associations with their hosts. Lepidoptera (butterfly and moth) larvae may feed parasitically on only a single plant, or they may graze on several nearby plants. It is therefore wise to treat this classification system as <a6_0>a continuum<a6_0/> rather than <b11_0>four<b11_0/> isolated forms.
